Anna Lorimer.name: Anna Lorimer
Anna Lorimer.title: Zip, Zip, Oh no!
Anna Lorimer.bio: Anna is a student at the University of Waterloo with a really long degree name. She’s an intern NCC Group and has worked in the UWaterloo CrySP lab. She has a cat named Lemon who is a real sourpuss. /
Anna Lorimer.abstract: You’ve probably heard the saying “Don’t Roll Your Own Crypto”, but what does that actually mean? In this talk we’ll have a look at the the catastrophically ineffective PKZIP encryption algorithm that Linux’s zip tool initially used, an attack against it, and what this failure can teach us about implementing encryption algorithms today.

Andrew Ling.name: Andrew Ling
Andrew Ling.title: FPGAs: the perfect spatial processor
Andrew Ling.bio: Andrew Ling is an engineering manager for the FPGA deep learning acceleration team in Intel's Toronto Technology Centre.  He received his Ph.D. from the University of Toronto in 2009.
Andrew Ling.abstract: Von Neuman Architectures are so 1990 - FPGAs: the perfect spatial processor for 2020 and beyond and how to program to it

Arshia Mufti.name: Arshia Mufti
Arshia Mufti.title: Wrinkles in Timekeeping: How Time is Tracked in Distributed Systems
Arshia Mufti.bio: Arshia is a research student in the Data Systems Group at the University of Waterloo, an organizer of StarCon, and probably hungry right about now.
Arshia Mufti.abstract: Tracking time is easy for humans, but why is it so hard for computers? When a group of computers talk to each other, a critical component of their communication is the way they keep time. Mechanisms like hardware clocks, logical timestamps, and NTP (network time protocol) have all been used to try to solve the same problem: how can distributed systems track time in synchrony? This talk will cover the timekeeping mechanisms used by popular databases today, but more broadly, explore what time fundamentally *means* to a computer system.

Ridwan Howlader.name: Ridwan Howlader
Ridwan Howlader.title: Impactful & Multidisciplinary Innovation
Ridwan Howlader.bio: Ridwan Howlader is the Executive Director of the University of Toronto Aerospace Team. He is a multidisciplinary leader who is passionate about facilitating growth of innovative and high-impact teams.
Ridwan Howlader.abstract: Planes, trains, automobiles, spacecraft, laptops, cameras, light bulbs, microwave ovens... the list could go on. Some of these are very conventional every day items, while others are technological marvels. All of these items have had a significant impact on society and its technical advancements. The development of software and design tools has advanced multidisciplinary innovation. The culture of digitization has enabled the growth of automation, and has resulted in an enriched quality of life. Students can capitalize on opportunities in these fields and potentially have a large impact.

Stephen Piron.name: Stephen Piron
Stephen Piron.title: Connecting the Dots with DeepLearni.ng
Stephen Piron.bio: Stephen is co-founder of DeepLearni.ng, a company that builds real-world AI for enterprises. Stephen is also a UofT Comp Sci and IEEE alum, and used to avidly await the latest editions of Spectrum.
Stephen Piron.abstract: What kind of future are you building? In 2018, AI--and especially deep learning--has captured the imagination of many. Connect the dots and discover what's led to the field's current success in Toronto and around the world with DeepLearni.ng’s co-founder Stephen Piron.

Andrew Louis.name: Andrew Louis
Andrew Louis.title: Five centuries of logging
Andrew Louis.bio: Andrew is a software developer from Toronto and a UofT CS grad. He’s currently building a Memex. Previously, he was the co-founder and CTO of ShopLocket, an ecommerce startup acquired in 2014.
Andrew Louis.abstract: Five hundred years ago, someone figured out that throwing a pice of wood into the water could help measure a ship’s speed. These numbers were recorded in a book and “logging” was born! Over time, these ships evolved to include both quantitative data (ship’s speed, direction) and qualitative data (weather, mermaid sightings (yes actually!)).   As software developers and technologists, logs are a crucial part of our tool belt. I’ll go over the 500-year history of logging and explore how the nautical culture that gave us logs might offer us lessons for making us more effective at our craft.

Gary Saarenvirta.name: Gary Saarenvirta
Gary Saarenvirta.title: Applied Artificial Intelligence
Gary Saarenvirta.bio: I am the founder and CEO of Daisy Intelligence. My passion is using AI to significantly grow bottom-line organizational profits, lowering the cost of living for all humanity and minimizing poverty.
Gary Saarenvirta.abstract: There is a lot of hype about artificial intelligence.  I will share Daisy's definition of artificial intelligence and share some missing ideas that I  believe are not being discussed in the popular culture today that are critical to developing practical and world changing AI solutions.  I will also discuss the success we have had with our customers applying artificial intelligence to business today.
